title: 107_hr642
content: Reauthorization of the Chesapeake Bay Office under Section 307 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992. The Secretary of Commerce shall establish the Chesapeake Bay Office within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Office will be headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary of Commerce with knowledge and experience in Chesapeake Bay research or resource management. The Director may appoint additional personnel as needed. The Office will provide technical assistance to federal, state, and local government agencies in consultation with the Chesapeake Executive Council. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will develop a strategy to assist the Chesapeake Bay Program in assessing processes, identifying alternatives for restoration, and monitoring management plans. The Chesapeake Bay Program coordinates various organizations within NOAA, Chesapeake Bay Regional Sea Grant Programs, and National Estuarine Research Reserve System for coastal research, fisheries assessments, data management, remote sensing, coastal management, and habitat conservation. The Cooperative Oxford Laboratory of the National Ocean Service coordinates programs on nonindigenous species, marine species pathology, human pathogens, and ecosystem health. It also ensures coordination between NOAA, EPA, and other agencies, and establishes peer review mechanisms for projects. The Office must ensure projects have scientific merit, assist in disseminating project results, and submit biennial reports to Congress and the Secretary of Commerce on Chesapeake Bay protection progress. The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration must submit proposals for continuing new activities in the Chesapeake Bay and integrating them with partners' activities to meet the commitments of the Chesapeake 2000 agreement and subsequent agreements. The Office of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, in collaboration with the Chesapeake Executive Council, will implement a program for community-based fishery and habitat restoration grants in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Grants will support projects by eligible entities to restore fisheries and habitats, with the Federal share not exceeding 75 percent. Eligible projects include various restoration efforts in the Chesapeake Bay. The program will provide grants for fishery and habitat restoration in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Eligible projects include improving fish passageways, creating reefs, restoring wetlands, producing oysters, and controlling nonindigenous species. Eligible entities include government entities in the watershed and organizations in the Chesapeake Bay. The program will provide grants for fishery and habitat restoration in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Eligible organizations in the watershed, such as educational institutions or community organizations, must be tax-exempt under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code and coordinate with government entities. The Director may set additional requirements for the program. The Secretary of Commerce will include the funding request in the President's annual budget to Congress. The funding request for the Chesapeake Bay Office is included in the President's annual budget to Congress. The Chesapeake Executive Council consists of representatives from various states and agencies. $6,000,000 is authorized for the Department of Commerce for the Chesapeake Bay Office for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. A conforming amendment is made to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Marine Fisheries Program Authorization Act. Multiple Species Management Strategy is also addressed. The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office will conduct a 5-year study with the scientific community to understand living resources in the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem and develop a multiple species management strategy. The study under paragraph (1)(B) will determine the status and trends of fish and shellfish in the Chesapeake Bay, evaluate interactions among these species and other living resources, and recommend management actions for a healthy ecosystem. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 4, 2001.
